journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: H∞ control for a class of discrete-time switched systems with state constraints

contrib-group.aff: State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Process Industries, Northeastern University, China

author-notes.corresp: Qingyu Su, State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Process Industries, Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China. Email: dayu0518@163.com

abstract.p: This article investigates the H∞ control problem for a class of discrete-time switched systems with state constraints. The state constraints are converted into state saturations by limiting the state in a unit hypercube. An improved average dwell time method is presented to take into account different decay rates of a Lyapunov function related to an active subsystem according to whether the saturations occur or not. Switched state feedback controllers are designed such that the closed-loop switched system subjects to state constraints is asymptotically stable and achieves a weighted L2-gain. Sufficient conditions for H∞ control of the switched system with state constraints are first derived. An application to a longitudinal motion of highly maneuverable aircraft technology vehicle is given to illustrate the applicability and the effectiveness of the proposed method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Switched systems are an important class of hybrid systems, which consist of a family of continuous-time or discrete-time subsystems and a switching law that specifies the switching between them. A study on this class of systems has attracted much attention in recent years for its theoretical significance1–5 and practical importance.6–12 In the study of switched systems, the focuses have been on the problems of stability, stabilization and H∞ control.13,14 Many methods have been developed in the study of switched systems such as common Lyapunov function,15 multiple Lyapunov functions,16,17 and switched Lyapunov functions.18 Meanwhile, as a class of important design methods of switching laws, average dwell time (ADT) method19–22 is usually acknowledged to have more flexibility and availability in the study of switched systems.

Switched systems with disturbance are commonly found in practical control systems. Thus, as a topic beyond stability analysis and stabilization, H∞ control problem for a disturbed switched system has been widely studied.23,24 On the other hand, it is a well-known fact that many practical systems are inevitably subject to the impact of constraints, including state constraints, output constraints and control constraints.25,26 Particularly, the state-constrained switched systems widely appear in practical. For example, the angle of attack is restricted in an allowed range in the switched aircraft system.6 In addition, the current and the voltage are not allowed to exceed a given safety value in the switched resistor–inductor–capacitor (RLC) circuit11 and the switched buck-boost converter.27 At the same time, some achievements have been obtained on the H∞ control problem for switched systems with control constraints.28,29 However, to the best of our knowledge, the problems of H∞ control for switched systems with state constraints have not been addressed in the existing literature, which partly motivates our present work.

Another reason that inspires us for this study is as follows: as aforementioned, ADT is an effective method to discuss the stabilization and the H∞ control problems for switched systems. This design method is of course expected to be useful for the switched systems with state constraints. However, the ADT method is not appropriate to be directly extended to the switched systems with state constraints. It is well known that the minimum admissible ADT is computed by two parameters, that is, the decay rate of each Lyapunov function during the running time of the subsystem and the jump rate of the adjacent Lyapunov functions at switching instants. It is straightforward that such a setup of the common decay rate regardless of whether the saturations occur or not will give rise to a certain conservativeness. Besides, it is worth noting that for a switched system without state constraints, the state trajectory is always smooth during the running time of each subsystem, and the nonsmooth state trajectory only appears at the switching times. Nevertheless, for a switched system with state constraints, the situation is completely different. In fact, the nonsmooth state not only appears at the switching times but also appears at the instants when the state becomes saturated from unsaturated, or becomes unsaturated from saturated, during the running time of each subsystem. Therefore, how to improve the standard ADT method to better deal with the switched systems with state constraints is worthwhile to proceed, which is another reason to motivate our present study.

This article is concerned with the H∞ control problem for a class of discrete-time switched systems with state constraints. The system is defined on a closed hypercube as all state variables are constrained to a unit hypercube. For this reason, the state-constrained switched system is sometimes referred to as a switched system subject to state saturations. An improved ADT method is presented to take into account different decay rates of a Lyapunov function related to an active subsystem according to whether the saturations occur or not. Switched state feedback controller is designed such that the closed-loop switched system with state constraints is asymptotically stable and achieves a weighted L2-gain. Sufficient conditions for state feedback control are derived and formulated in terms of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). The minimum admissible ADT and the corresponding state feedback controllers are obtained from the LMI conditions.

The main contributions of this article include the following aspects: First, a new ADT method is proposed. Applying this method produces a smaller ADT than the standard ADT method due to different decay rates of a Lyapunov function related to an active subsystem are adopted according to whether the saturations occur or not. Second, sufficient conditions for the H∞ control of a class of discrete-time switched systems with state constraints are first derived.

This article is organized as follows: “Problem statement” provides the problem statements and preliminaries. The H∞ control problem of the switched system with state constraints is investigated in “Main results.” In “Algorithm,” an iterative algorithm is introduced for verifying the solvability of proposed LMIs. A practical example is then given, followed by some concluding remarks in the final section.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: Throughout this article, the following notations are used. ℝn denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space, and ℤ+ represents the set of nonnegative integers. ℒ2[0,∞) is the Lebesgue space consisting of all discrete-time vector-valued functions that are square-summable over [0,1,2…,∞). The ℒ2-norm of a causal vector signal x(k) with bounded energy is ∥x(k)∥=(∑k=0∞∥x(k)∥2)1/2. In addition, the Hermitian part of a square matrix M is denoted by He(M):=M+MT. Finally, a function ceil (ε) represents rounding real number ε to the nearest integer greater than or equal to ε.

sec.title: Problem statement
sec.p: Consider a class of discrete-time switched systems with state constraints described by

where x(k)=(x1(k),x2(k),…,xn(k))T∈𝔻n={−1≤xi(k)≤1,∀i∈N}∈ℝn,N={1,2,…,n} is the constrained state, u(k)∈ℝp is the control input, ω(k)∈ℝr is the disturbance input that belongs to L2[0,∞) and z(k)∈ℝq is the controlled output. σ(k) is a piecewise constant function of time, called a switching signal, which takes its values in the finite set 𝒫={1,2,…,m}, m is the number of subsystems. In addition, for a switching sequence 0<k1<…<ki<…, symbol ki denotes the moment of the ith switching. When σ(k)=p, we say that the pth subsystem is active, and we define the symbol pi denotes that the pth subsystem is active for the ith switching.
The function h(·) in equation (1) is defined by the following general formulation
with, for each i∈N
where matrix 𝒜=[𝒜1T,…,𝒜nT]T∈ℝn×n and ξ(k)=[ξ1(k),…,ξn(k)]T∈𝔻n.
In this article, we are interested in designing state feedback controllers
where Kp are the controller gains to be determined. Then, the resulting closed-loop system is given by
where Ap:=Ap+BpKp, Cp:=Cp+DpKp.

sec.title: Remark 1
sec.p: The nonswitched continuous-time version of system (1) is established in studies by Hou and Michel30 and Ji et al.31 In view of the definition of the function h(·), if the state does not touch the boundary ±1, the state trajectory will run without any influence from h(·) inside the region. If the state touches the boundary and will exceed the boundary at next sampling time, then the h(·) will force the state to not increase any more to avoid violation of the boundary. Obviously, for system (1), according to equation (3), the function h(·) is not continuous with respect to time, and the state of system (1) is nonsmooth not only at the switching points but also at the points of the saturations occurrence and disappearance during the running time of each subsystem. This is a significant distinction between the system (1) and the switched system without state constraints.

Our objective is formulated as follows: Given a switched system (1) with state constraints and a prescribed level of disturbance attenuation level γ>0, find a set of admissible switching signals and design the corresponding state feedback controllers (4), such that the closed-loop system (5) is globally uniformly asymptotically stable (GUAS) operating on the unit hypercube Dn in Rn and achieves a prescribed weighted L2-gain.

sec.title: Remark 2
sec.p: GUAS refers to the stability operating on the unit hypercube 𝔻n rather than the usual ℝn. In other words, by GUAS of the origin we mean that the origin is locally uniformly asymptotically stable (LUAS) within 𝔻n, instead of the usual ℝn, being the domain of attraction. This expression is widely employed in the relevant literatures, which study the stability problem of the state-constrained systems, see, for example, Hou and Michel30 and Liu and Michel.32
Before proceeding, it is necessary to recall the definition of the ADT and the stability results for switched nonlinear systems with ADT.

sec.title: Definition 1.19
sec.p: For a switching signal σ(k) and each k2≥k1≥0, let Nσ(k)(k2,k1) denote the number of discontinuities of σ(k) in the open interval (k1,k2). We say that σ(k) has an ADT τa if there exist two positive numbers N0 and τa such that

sec.title: Remark 3
sec.p: Definition 1 means that if there exists a positive number τa such that a switching signal has the ADT property, namely, the ADT between any two consecutive switching is no smaller than a common constant τa for all subsystems.

sec.title: Lemma 1.33
sec.p: Consider the discrete-time switched system x(k+1)=fσ(k)(x(k)),σ(k)∈𝒫 and let 0<λ<1, μ>1 be the given constants. Suppose that there exist positive definite C1 functions Vσ(k):ℝn→ℝ and two class K∞ functions κ1 and κ2 such that ∀p∈𝒫
and ∀(σ(ki)=p,σ(ki−)=q)∈𝒫×𝒫,p≠q
then the system is GUAS for any switching signal with ADT

sec.title: Definition 2.18
sec.p: For γ>0 and 0<ζ<1, system (1) is said to have a weighted L2-gain, if under zero initial condition x=0, it holds that
for all nonzero ω(k)∈ℒ2[0,∞).

sec.title: Remark 4
sec.p: The weighted L2-gain performance means that the disturbance attenuation performance is different when the decay degree of the system is different. The scalar ζ symbolizes the decreasing rate of the multiple Lyapunov functions to be constructed for each subsystem. When ζ→0, the weighted L2-gain will approach the normal L2-gain.

sec.p: Given the symmetric matrix A=[A11A12A21A22], the following statements are equivalent.

sec.title: Main results
sec.p: Let ki and ki+1, ∀i∈ℤ+, denote the starting time and ending time of the active subsystem, while 𝕋f[ki,ki+1) and 𝕋s[ki,ki+1), imply the total intervals during which the state is saturated and unsaturated within the interval [ki,ki+1), respectively. Meanwhile Tf(ki,ki+1) and Ts(ki,ki+1) imply the corresponding length of 𝕋f[ki,ki+1) and 𝕋s[ki,ki+1), respectively. Then, we denote Tf(k0,k):=∑j=1iTf(kj−1,kj)+Tf(ki,k) and Ts(k0,k):=∑j=1iTs(kj−1,kj)+Ts(ki,k). Moreover, let α and β denote different decay rates of a Lyapunov function related to an active subsystem corresponding to whether the saturations occur or not, and we suppose that α>β.

sec.title: Lemma 3
sec.p: Let α, β, and μ be the given constants satisfying 1>α>β>0, μ≥1. If there exist some piecewise continuous functions Vp(x(k)):𝔻n→ℝ, for all p∈𝒫, such that

then the switched system (5) with state constraints is GUAS and has a weighted L2-gain γ for any switching signal with ADT

sec.title: Remark 5
sec.p: It is noted that the improved ADT (10) associated with two different decay rates is always smaller than standard ADT (6) associated with only one common decay rate, since 0<β<ζ<α<1. Also note that if we choose α=β, then equation (10) will readily reduce to equation (6), thus, Lemma 1 can be regarded as a special case of Lemma 3.

sec.title: Remark 6
sec.p: In some cases, if Tsmax is known in advance, and the value of Tsmax satisfies Tsmax≤(ln(1−ζ)−ln(1−α))lnμ/(ln(1−β)−ln(1−ζ))ln(1−β), we can establish another improved ADT described as follows
where Tsmax=supi∈ℤ+{Ts(ki,ki+1)}.

It can be seen clearly that equation (20) presents a more general ADT than equation (6), which corresponds to the special case Tsmax=0 (i.e. the saturations never occur), thus the ADT (6) in Lemma 1 can be also regarded as a special case of equation (20). Also note that both of the above two improved ADT (10) and ADT (20) are smaller than the standard ADT (6). Furthermore, in this case, it is easy to show that ADT (20) is smaller than ADT (10).

As aforementioned, there are several methods to handle the saturations. Here, we introduce a convex hull method from34 which translates the saturation function h(·) into the vertex of a convex hull to deal with the saturations.
Let Ln be the set of n×n diagonal matrices whose diagonal elements are either 1 or 0. For example, if n=2, then
Obviously, there are 2n elements in Ln. Suppose that each element of Ln is labeled as Ls,s∈L:={1,2,…,2n} and denote Ls−=I−Ls. Clearly, Ls− is also an element of Ln if Ls∈Ln. Then, we know that

for any matrix Ξ∈ℝn independent of x and where G=[gij]∈ℝn×n is row diagonally dominant and the diagonal is composed of negative elements, that is, the matrix G satisfies |gii|>∑j=1,j≠in|gij| and gii<0, for all i∈N.
Now, we are in a position to give the existence conditions of H∞ state feedback controllers for the state-constrained switched system (1) with the ADT associated with saturations.

sec.title: Theorem 1
sec.p: Let α, β, μ be some given constants satisfying 1>α>β>0, μ≥1. If there exist positive matrices Qp, row diagonally dominant matrices Gp and matrices Fp,Hp, p∈𝒫 such that ∀(p,q)∈𝒫×𝒫, p≠q, s∈S, Ls≠I

then the switched system (1) is GUAS and has a weighted L2-gain γ for any switching signal with ADT satisfying (10). Moreover, if equations (22) to (24) are feasible, the controller gains can be given by

sec.p: Choose the Lyapunov functions as follows

Assuming that equation (22) is feasible, it is to see that Qp−He(Hp)<0, which means that Hp is nonsingular. Due to Qp>0, it can be seen that (Qp−Hp)TQp−(Qp−Hp)≥0, which implies −HpTQpHp≤Qp−He(Hp). In addition, PpandPq are all positive definite matrices, then Qp>0andQq>0. Then we have equation (24) equivalent to Pp<μPq. Thus, if equations (22) to (24) are feasible, the admissible controller gains can be given by Kp=FpHp−1, which completes the proof.

sec.title: Algorithm
sec.p: In this section, we will follow the idea of Fang and Lin34 to propose an iterative LMI algorithm for verifying the sufficient conditions of theorems for the discrete-time case. Let V be the set of n-dimensional row vectors in which there is only one nonzero element, which is 1. Let υi,i∈N be an element of V in which the ith element is 1. Let Wi be the set of n-dimensional column vectors in which the ith element is 1, and other elements are either 1 or −1. The elements of Wi are denoted as ωij,j∈M:={1,…,2n−1}. Then, the condition that each Gp is row diagonally dominant and the diagonal is composed of negative elements can be expressed as the following LMIs
Now, we will give the algorithm step by step as follows.

list-item.p: Step 1. Give the constant γ and Wp>0. Solve Qp, Fp and Hp from the following Lyapunov equation
where Kp=FpHp−1 are chosen such that Ap+BpKp are Hurwitz.

sec.p: Set k=0

list-item.p: Step 2. Using Qp, Fp and Hp obtained previously solves the following LMI optimization problem for Gp and η
If k=0 and η≤0, go to Step 4. If k>0, η≤0 or η≰ηk, go to Step 4. Otherwise, set k=k+1, ηk=η, go to the next step.
Step 3. Using Gp obtained in the previous step solves the following LMI optimization problem for Qp, Fp, Hp and η
If η≤0 or η≰ηk, go to Step 4. Otherwise, set k=k+1, ηk=η, go to Step 2.

Step 4. If η≤0, the system (5) is GUAS at the origin. And the current Kp is the calculated feedback again. Otherwise, no conclusion can be drawn. A different Wp may be selected and the algorithm may be repeated from Step 1.

sec.title: Remark 7
sec.p: We note that solutions to the LMI optimization problems in algorithm always exist, and αk is nonincreasing. This fact is discussed in many literatures, see studies of Fang and Lin,34 Cao et al.35 and Boyd et al.36 As a result, one concludes that this iterative LMI algorithm is convergent. Nevertheless, the number of constraints increases exponentially as n, the order of the system, increases. The large number of constraints may cause numerical difficulties.34,36

sec.title: Example
sec.p: In this section, highly maneuverable aircraft technology (HiMAT) vehicle given in the study by Hou et al.12 is taken as an example to illustrate the effectiveness of our design method. For statement convenience, we select two operating points within the flight envelope as depicted in Table 1 and construct a switched system using longitudinal short period linear models.

caption.p: Two operation points of HiMAT vehicle.

sec.p: Assume that the two linear models can describe the dynamic behavior of HiMAT vehicle in the neighborhood of the two operating points. Using the zero-order hold equivalent method, with a sample time T=0.1s, we obtain the discrete-time switched system consisting of two subsystems. The state is x=[x1,x2], where x1 and x2 denote the angle of attack and the pitch rate, respectively. The parameters are

Given parameters α=0.3,β=0.2andμ=1.4, and choosing the switching signal satisfying (Tf(0,k)−1)/Ts(0,k)=1, then we set ζ=0.25, and the minimal ADT can be calculated as τa*=2. Given γ=0.5, we can obtain the controller gains by solving the LMI equations (22) to (24) with the algorithm

The switching signal satisfying ADT τa=2 is shown in Figure 1. Given the initial state x0=[1,1]T, the simulation result of the trajectory of the closed-loop system both with state constraints and without state constraints is shown in Figure 2. Comparing Figure 2(a) and (b), we can find that in the state x1(t) of the closed-loop system, saturations occur. It can also be seen from Figure 2(a) of the trajectory of the state that although x1(t) has caused saturations, the closed-loop system is GUAS with the given initial state, under the switching signal designed by our method, which adequately illustrates the applicability and the effectiveness of the proposed method. Figure 3 gives the validation on the weighted L2-gain γ index that the resulting switched system with state constraint can achieve when applying the controller (35) under switching signal as shown in Figure 1. It can be observed from Figure 3 that the weighted L2-gain γ index is valid with γ=0.004<0.5 for the controller (35) designed by our method.

caption.p: Switch signal with the ADT τa≥3.
Saturated trajectory of the closed-loop system under switching signal with τa=3: (a) the trajectory with state constraints and (b) the trajectory without state constraints.
Weighted L2-gain γ index for switched system with constraint by controller (35).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The H∞ control problem of a class of discrete-time switched systems with state constraints has been studied in this article. There are three points that deserve to be summarized again. First, a key point is to take into account the fact that the state of switched system with state constraints is nonsmooth, not only at the switching times but also at the instants when the state becomes saturated from unsaturated during the running time of each subsystem. Second, an improved ADT method that adopts different decay rates of a Lyapunov function related to an active subsystem according to whether the saturations occur or not is proposed. By using this method, a smaller ADT can be obtained than the standard ADT. Third, we have established the sufficient conditions of H∞ control of the switched system with state constraints first; furthermore, the corresponding H∞ state feedback controllers are designed via the technique of LMIs.
